questions.question:
Question 1: You decide to start recombinant growth hormone therapy in a child with idiopathic short 
stature. The treatment primarily works by the activation of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Growth hormone primarily acts through activation of the JAK-STAT signaling pathway. Cytokines such as interferon-gamma and prolactin hormone also act by the JAK STAT pathway.

questions.question: Question 2: In which of the following conditions is growth hormone therapy not indicated?
questions.explanation:
604 
Sold by @itachibot Growth hormone therapy is not indicated in Sotos syndrome. Indications for GH therapy are: • GH Deficiency in children & adults • AIDS-associated wasting • Malabsorption associated with the short-bowel syndrome (As GH stimulates the adaptation of GI 
epithelial cells). • Children with other conditions associated with short stature despite adequate GH production: • Turner syndrome • Noonan syndrome • Prader-Willi syndrome • Chronic renal insufficiency • Small for gestational age babies • Idiopathic short stature Sotos syndrome (cerebral gigantism) is characterized by excessive physical growth during the first 
few years of life resulting in a disproportionately large and long head with a slightly protrusive 
forehead, large hands and feet, hypertelorism, and down-slanting eyes. It is accompanied by mild 
cognitive impairment, developmental abnormalities, hypotonia, and speech abnormalities. The image given below shows a large head, large hands, and characteristic eye features in a child 
with Sotos syndrome.

questions.question: Question 3: All of the following are sound advice to the respective patients except:
questions.explanation:
GH deferral is only recommended for the first year after treatment of leukemia. 605 
Sold by @itachibot Because of the anti-insulin action of GH, there is an increased incidence of type 2 diabetes 
mellitus and therefore, fasting glucose levels should be monitored periodically during GH 
therapy. Due to the rare potential for developing intracranial hypertension, fundoscopic 
examination is recommended at the initiation of therapy and at periodic intervals thereafter. 
Rapid growth induced by GH can cause slipped epiphyses or scoliosis in children. Estrogens (OCPs and estrogen supplements) inhibit GH action so that a larger dose is needed to 
maintain the same IGF-1 level. The adverse effects of growth hormone are: Children

questions.question:
Question 4: A middle-aged man with tall stature, frontal bossing, prognathism, large hands, and feet is 
started on a growth hormone receptor antagonist. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario depicts acromegaly. Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor 
antagonist that is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly. Octreotide and lanreotide are synthetic somatostatin analogs that can be used in the management 
of acromegaly. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist used primarily to treat hyperprolactinemia also has an 
indication in the management of acromegaly.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 23-year-old lady presented to the gynecology OPD with complaints of amenorrhea and 
milky discharge from her breasts. Her urine pregnancy test is negative and her serum 
prolactin level is 175 µg/L. The resident prescribes a long-acting D2 agonist. Which of the 
following drugs is she likely to have been prescribed?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario depicts hyperprolactinemia. Cabergoline is a long-acting D2 agonist. Its t1/2 is >60 hours. It is indicated for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia and acromegaly. Bromocriptine, lisuride, and apomorphine are short-acting when compared with cabergoline. Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid derivative used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus, 
hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, and Parkinson's disease. Cabergoline is preferred over 
bromocriptine for hyperprolactinemia due to lower adverse effects such as nausea and also due to 
dosing advantage (twice a week instead of daily dosing). Lisuride is indicated in early Parkinson's disease but is also known to decrease prolactin levels 
and prevent migraine attacks. Apomorphine is a morphine derivative used to treat hypomobile 
"off" episodes of advanced Parkinson's disease.

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following conditions is octreotide not used?
questions.explanation:
606 
Sold by @itachibot Octreotide is not used in glioma. Uses of octreotide are : • Secretory diarrhea in carcinoid syndrome and VIPoma • Short bowel syndrome, AIDS • Pituitary tumors causing acromegaly • Islet cell tumors like glucagonoma, insulinoma • Acute bleeding in esophageal varices • Thyrotrope adenoma Adverse effects include gall stones, sinus bradycardia, and conduction abnormalities. Vit B12 
deficiency can occur on long term use.

questions.question: Question 7: Valvular heart disease is not associated with the use of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Quinagolide is not associated with valvular heart disease. Quinagolide is a non-ergot D2 receptor agonist. Cabergoline, Bromocriptine, and Pergolide are ergot derivatives and are associated with valvular 
heart disease. The risk of valvular heart disease from ergot therapy is associated with higher doses 
of the drug (necessary for Parkinson's disease treatment) but not with the lower doses used in 
treating hyperprolactinemia. Note: Pergolide was withdrawn from the market due to reports of serious valve damage.

questions.question: Question 8: In which of the following patients is bromocriptine not indicated?

options.c: A 23-year old lady with endogenous depression
options.d: A 45-year old parkinson's patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.explanation:
Bromocriptine is not indicated in endogenous depression. It is a semisynthetic ergot D2 receptor agonist. Uses of bromocriptine: • Hyperprolactinemia (causing galactorrhoea, amenorrhea, or infertility in women 
and gynecomastia or infertility in men) • Parkinsonism • Acromegaly • Type 2 diabetes mellitus • Hepatic coma • Supression of lactation 607 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic patient with a history of coronary bypass surgery presents 
with haematemesis to the casualty. An upper GI endoscopy shows the following finding. 
Which of the following drugs will you administer to this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history of the patient and the endoscopic image showing prominent cherry-red 
spots are suggestive of bleeding esophageal varices. Octreotide is indicated in the treatment of acute variceal bleeding. It is a somatostatin analog that 
reduces azygous blood flow significantly and decreases variceal bleeding. Other drugs that can be used for the management of bleeding esophageal varices: • Terlipressin • Vasopressin • Propranolol Option A: Desmopressin is a selective V2 receptor agonist used for central diabetes insipidus and 
nocturnal enuresis. Option B: Propranolol (non-selective beta-blocker) is used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding 
and not in its acute management. Option D: Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor used for bleeding esophageal varices but may 
compromise cardiac function and induce ischemia and hence can't be used in this case. Note: Although terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor and is be used for bleeding oesophagal varices, the 
patient in this scenario has a history of MI (undergone coronary bypass surgery). Terlipressin can 
compromise cardiac function (reduces cardiac output and ejection fraction) and induce ischemia. 
Hence, it is not preferred in this case.

questions.question:
Question 10: Pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist is used for the treatment of  
.
questions.explanation:
Pulsatile administration of GnRH agonists results in increased FSH and LH secretion and is 
therefore used to treat male and female infertility. Non-pulsatile or continuous dose of GnRH agonist results in suppression and decreased 
concentrations of gonadotropins LH and FSH. They are used in: • Endometriosis • Uterine fibroids • Central precocious puberty • Ca prostate • Ca ovary and breast • Controlled ovary stimulation

questions.question:
Question 11: A 30-year-old lady who is suffering from dysmenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with 
endometriosis. She has been prescribed an intranasal spray containing a GnRH agonist. What 
is the likely drug?

options.b: Increase the dose as pregnancy causes an increased demand for levothyroxine
options.c: Continue the same dose but monitor the serum levels on a fortnightly basis
options.d: Stop levothyroxine till the end of the first trimester as it has teratogenic potential

questions.explanation:
Nafarelin is a GnRH agonist administered via nasal spray. 608 
Sold by @itachibot It is approved for use in endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Routes of administration of other GnRH agonists: • Intranasal and subcutaneous - Buserelin • Intramuscular and subcutaneous - Leuprolide • Subcutaneous implants - Histrelin and Goserelin Some GnRH antagonists are: • Degarelix • Ganirelix • Cetrorelix (Synthetic) All GnRH antagonists are administered subcutaneously. 609 
Sold by @itachibot Thyroid and Antithyroid Agents
